content: The University of Arizona College of Engineering (Electrical & Computer Engineering) offers Software Engineering–related research opportunities through external research centers and internal faculty research areas. Students can explore external centers focused on topics like solar energy, cloud computing, quantum networks, and healthcare streaming, as well as internal research groups spanning autonomous systems, biomedical technologies, computer architecture, quantum information, and software engineering.

metadata.college: College of Engineering - Electrical & Computer Engineering

content: The Arizona Research Institute for Solar Energy (AzRISE) is an external research center at the University of Arizona that addresses large-scale, affordable solar energy generation and workforce training needs. Its work includes identifying and funding Arizona-specific solar energy research, developing intellectual property, and promoting the widespread adoption of solar energy technologies.

metadata.center_name: Arizona Research Institute for Solar Energy (AzRISE)
metadata.description: Response to the challenge of planning for large-scale, affordable solar energy power generation and training the workforce that will make the transition possible. Research goals include identifying, funding and coordinating Arizona-specific solar energy research opportunities, developing intellectual property, and promoting development and widespread adoption of solar energy.

content: The Broadband Wireless Access & Applications Center (BWAC) is an external research center where researchers develop technology and standards for flexible, efficient, reliable, and secure wireless access and applications. Funded by the National Science Foundation, BWAC collaborates with industry and academic partners to address the rapid growth in wireless data traffic and shape future wireless technologies.

metadata.description: Researchers are developing technology and standards to create flexible, efficient, reliable and secure wireless access and application solutions to support the tremendous growth in wireless data traffic. BWAC is funded by the National Science Foundation and works with industry and academic partners to pursue large-scale research programs and create new visions for the wireless industry.

content: The Center for Quantum Networks (CQN) is a National Science Foundation Engineering Research Center led by the University of Arizona with core partners at Harvard, MIT, and Yale. CQN focuses on quantum materials science, quantum and classical processing at network nodes, and quantum network protocols and architectures, with the goal of demonstrating a U.S.-based quantum network that distributes quantum information at high speed over long distances to multiple users.

metadata.description: National Science Foundation Engineering Research Center led by the University of Arizona, with core partners Harvard University, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Yale University. The CQN team's research areas include advancing quantum materials science, quantum and classical processing required at a network node, and quantum network protocols and architectures. CQN also aims to demonstrate the first U.S.-based quantum network that can distribute quantum information at high speeds, over long distances, to multiple user groups.

content: The Center for Semiconductor Manufacturing (CSM) develops advanced technology solutions for global semiconductor demand and workforce training, supporting sustainable economic development and national security. Its chip design program covers analog and digital designs and new architectures for applications ranging from everyday devices to biomedical engineering, defense, green energy, and photonic and CMOS+X materials.

metadata.description: Develops advanced technology solutions for global demand and workforce training that promotes sustainable economic development and national security. The Chip Design program focuses on analog and digital designs, as well as architecture for new training. Applications range from everyday devices to ultramodern technology for biomedical engineering, defense, green energy, and photonic and CMOS+X materials.

content: The Center to Stream Healthcare In Place (C2SHIP) is a National Science Foundation Engineering Research Center led by the University of Arizona with partners including Baylor College of Medicine, USC, and Caltech. C2SHIP’s mission is to develop in-place healthcare technologies, promote healthcare equity, design wearable sensors, and create machine learning models to extract and visualize clinically meaningful information for providers and patients.

metadata.center_name: Center to Stream Healthcare In Place
metadata.description: National Science Foundation Engineering Research Center led by the University of Arizona in partnership with Baylor College of Medicine, University of Southern California and Caltech. Its mission is to engage academic and industrial partners in developing in-place health care technologies and help establish healthcare equity. In addition to researching the design and manufacture of wearable sensors, the team is also developing machine learning models to extract meaningful information from these sensors and display it for care providers and patients.

content: The Cloud and Autonomic Computing Center (CAC) is a National Science Foundation Industry–University Cooperative Research Center focused on designing self-managed information systems and services. Its research spans cloud computing systems and applications, storage and networking, data center design, cybersecurity, and systems software.

metadata.description: National Science Foundation Industry and University Cooperative Research Center with a focus on the research and design of information systems and services that are self-managed with minimal involvement by users and administrators. The center broadly encompasses cloud computing systems and applications including storage and networking, data center design, cybersecurity and systems software.

content: The Autonomous Systems, Communications and Robotics research area focuses on autonomous systems, communication technologies, robotics, and control systems. Multiple ECE faculty work in this area, offering opportunities in topics like intelligent control, robotic systems, and advanced communications for autonomous platforms.

The Biomedical Technologies research area covers biomedical engineering, medical imaging, wearable sensors, and other healthcare-related technologies. Faculty in this area explore novel devices and systems to improve health diagnostics, monitoring, and treatment.

The Circuits, Microelectronics and Very-Large-Scale Integration research area focuses on circuit design, microelectronics, and VLSI, including integrated circuits and chip design. This area supports semiconductor and hardware-focused research relevant to embedded and software-hardware co-design.

The Communications, Coding and Information Theory research area explores communication systems, coding theory, information theory, and signal processing. Faculty work on advanced coding schemes, communication protocols, and theoretical foundations for modern communication networks.

The Computer Architecture and Cloud/Distributed Computing research area focuses on modern computer architectures, cloud computing, distributed systems, and high-performance computing. Faculty investigate efficient hardware–software co-design, scalable cloud platforms, and distributed computing frameworks relevant to software engineering.

The Optics, Photonics and Terahertz Devices and Systems research area centers on optical and photonic devices, terahertz systems, and optical communications. This area supports research at the intersection of hardware, materials, and high-speed communication technologies.

metadata.research_area: Optics, Photonics and Terahertz Devices and Systems

content: The Quantum Information Science and Engineering research area covers quantum computing, quantum networks, quantum information, and quantum communication. Faculty work on fundamental theory and practical implementations of quantum technologies.

The Signal, Image and Video Processing research area focuses on algorithms and systems for processing signals, images, and video. Topics include computer vision, pattern recognition, and advanced signal processing techniques that support applications from communications to medical imaging.

The Software Engineering and Embedded Systems research area directly overlaps with the SFWE program, focusing on software engineering methods, embedded and real-time systems, and complex system design. Faculty in this area supervise projects on embedded software, system integration, and high-reliability software systems.

The Wireless Networking, Security and Systems research area investigates wireless networks, network and cybersecurity, 5G/6G systems, and IoT security. It brings together faculty working on secure, high-performance wireless and networked systems that are highly relevant to modern software and cyber-physical systems.
